entry.title: Transferring Verifiable Credentials with the Eclipse Dataspace Decentralized Claims Protocol (DCP)
entry.content:
In the era of Self-sovereign Identity (SIS), verifiable credentials (VCs) are becoming a cornerstone. Organizations and individuals can now issue, request, and present attestations  without relying on a central authority, enabled by emerging standards and protocols such as the Decentral Claims Protocol (DCP). This blog post explores two core ways VCs are transferred from an issuer wallet tenant to a holder wallet tenant using Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) focusing on automation options available to both issuers and holders.

 

Two VC Transfer Patterns

With DCP, there are two main patterns for moving a verifiable credential from the issuer's environment to the holder's:

Holder-Initiated Credential Request

Holder requests VCs:

  • The holder launches their VC request app and picks the issuer from which they wish to request credentials.
  • The app pulls published credential types (from the issuer's metadata endpoint), ensuring the holder can only request credentials the issuer offers. 

     
  • The users selects the credential types to be requested
  • Next, the holder selects which identity to use (think multiple DIDs or personas in their wallet).
  • A request for the selected credential type(s), tied to the chosen identity, is dispatched to the issuer.

 

API to Request VCs

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/requestCredentials/{app_name}
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "requestedCredentials": [
    {
      "credentialType": "BpnCredential",
      "format": "vcdm11_jwt"
    }
  ],
  "issuerDid": "{issuerDID}",
  "holderDid": "{holderDID}"
}

 

Issuer processes credential requests:

The issuer receives the request in their inbox. They review, approve, and send back the requested VC(s) to the holder. Alternatively, they may have to first create the credential before sending it.

Automation Option: Issuers can preconfigure their wallet to auto-respond to requests - if the VC is already ready. However, if credentials are not yet generated, or if the holder requests a set of credentials where not all are available, manual intervention is required.

Holder receives VCs:

Once complete, the holder receives the VC, visible in the credential overview section of their admin app. 


 

API to Respond to VC Requests

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

Issuer Get Received Credential Requests

GET {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialRequestsReceived
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

 

Response to VC Request -> Send Response to Request

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialRequestsReceived/{requestId}/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

 

Issuer-Initiated Credential Offer

Sometimes, the issuer wants to proactively notify holders that a credential is available or due for a refresh (e.g., before expiration or after key rotation). This issuing pattern is essential for refreshing credentials (e.g., after expiration or key revocation) because the issuer can push a new offer seamlessly, keeping the holder's status up to date with minimal friction.

Issuer sends offer

The issuer navigates their app to the relevant issued VC, opens the action menu, and sends a credential offer to the selected holder. The offer notifies the holder that a credential is prepped for them and can be retrieved.

Holder receives offer

The holder's wallet receives the offer. Here, behavior depends on their wallet's configuration:

  • Manual: The holder reviews the offer and chooses to make a credential request to receive it.
  • Automated: If the holder has marked the issuer as trusted with auto-accept enabled, the wallet will automatically convert the offer into a credential request and handle the entire transfer without manual clicks.

API to Offer VCs

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

 

POST {div_wallet_srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialOffers/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "credentials": [
    "{vcId}"
  ]
}

 

Flexible Automation for Different Needs

A core strength of DIV is its support for both manual and automated flows. Depending on policy, user preference, and business process, any step on either issuer or holder side can be handled by a human or managed entirely by the wallet‚Äôs auto-configuration. In highly regulated or sensitive use-cases, both sides might want maximum manual review steps before issuing or accepting credentials. In high-scale, low-touch environments, the entire process can be embedded and fully automated.

 

Summary

Decentralized identity verification, enables seamless, secure transfer of verifiable credentials across wallet tenants. Whether initiated by holders seeking new credentials or by proactive issuers keeping credentials fresh, DCP allows maximum flexibility for both manual and automated workflows letting each participant tailor the process to their risk profile and user experience needs.

Read more

  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Dataspaces
  • SAP help: Requesting VCs, Offering VCs
  • API documentation in detail
  • Decentralized Claims Protocol

entry.title: Automate sending of loading instructions - Keep block BLL status of TU
entry.content:
Hi experts  , 

need your support to find a way to automatically create the Transportation Unit (TU) in EWM based on the Freight Order (FO) recently created from the VSR optimizer in TM.

I‚Äôm aware that the standard program "/SCMTMS/TOR_FO_PROC_BATCH" can trigger this process when the Load Plan Status is set to "Finalized", but this doesn‚Äôt align with our current requirement. In our case, EWM needs the TU to remain blocked until customs approval is received for the FU/FO. Only after that, setting the status to "Load Plan Finalized" should unblock the TU in EWM and allow the process to continue.

The challenge is that EWM currently doesn‚Äôt have visibility into which FOs are still under customs clearance. That‚Äôs why we rely on blocking the TU based on status to control the flow.

So the question is:
üëâ Is there a PPF action or program that can send the loading instructions to EWM automatically without requiring the "Load Plan Finalized" status?

entry.title: In-House Kanban EWM without using planned or production orders
entry.content:
We are setting up a new production cell that would like to kit a complete tray of materials from a sub-assembly through kanban.

The idea is the kanban of the sub-assy is set to empty. 

A WT is created for each of the components in the BOM of the sub-assy

When confirmed the components are moved from the warehouse to the cell

Kanban is set it to full

The sub assy is confirmed via MFBF and components backflushed from the cell.

We don't want any planned or production orders being created, we just want it to replenish the material from the warehouse to the shopfloor. Is this even possible and if so could someone help outline what config etc is needed please?

entry.title: Re: CDS View for Monitor Purchase Order Items
entry.content:
Hello @AdamHorne 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at APIs in SAP Order and Delivery Scheduling, Purchase Order & Monitor Purchase Order Items for more details.

To summarise, the CDS view I_PurOrdScheduleLineAPI01 does not include delivered value and invoice value. These fields come from some other released CDS views.

I recommend enriching your custom CDS by joining them with I_PurchaseOrderDeliveryValuesAPI01 for delivered values. I_PurchaseOrderItemInvoiceValuesAPI01 for invoiced values.

Joining them will enable you replicate same figures you see in the app.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: FI-TV (Travel Management): S/4HANA and Enhancement Approach with PTK99
entry.content:
Hello folks,

I got a question regarding Migration Info in SAP Note 2719018 - S4TWL - SAP Travel Management in SAP S/4HANA Suite - SAP for Me .

In before: We are using FI-TV with heavily enhanced and partially modified database and business logic making usage of the Structure PTK99 which is reused in the PCL1-TE Cluster. We are solely using WebDynpro ABAP Apps for Enduser-Processes and SAPGUI Transactions which are not yet obsolete for power users. We do not use any Fiori Apps except for MTA (not MTR) rendered within the Fiori My Inbox.

My question concerns the following passage in the aforementioned note:

"(. . .)Table PTK99: The use of table PTK99 is not supported. Instead we provide an extensibility concept (please see SAP KBA 3296253 and 3260453). If you want to manage old data in the cluster corresponding to the structure PTK99, you will need to manage the mapping between the old structure (PTK99) and new structures yourself via extensibility concept.(. . .)"

This passage seems to be related only to the newly available Fiori Apps . However, at the same time, it does not explicitly state that the approach with PTK99 will still be supported for "the old stuff". Since the codeline is not changed aside from simplifications which (as far as I can tell) do not impede on this functionality, I'm 95% sure our approach should still be technically viable, but I would sleep better at night if somebody could confirm my thesis.

*Attempting to summon @FX-Vila *

Any replies are highly appreciated!

Cheers, Lukas

entry.title: üîµ Behind the Magic: How Cirque du Soleil Reimagined Invoice Management with SAP Business AI
entry.content:
Cirque du Soleil Entertainment Group is a global leader in live entertainment. With over 4,000 employees, approximately 1,200 of them artists from about 80 countries, their shows are known for artistry, theatrics, live music, and breathtaking performances.
Cirque du Soleil processes over 70,000 invoices per year from vendors all over the world. The Accounts Payable department was overwhelmed with invoice inquiries asking, ‚ÄúWhat is the status of my invoice?‚Äù
To address this, Cirque du Soleil turned to SAP Business AI. The new AI-powered Invoice Assistant automates the review and response process for invoice-related emails. Powered by SAP Business AI and built on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), the solution is already delivering faster response times, enhanced supplier experiences, and seamless multilingual automation.
In this session you will learn how automation keeps the show running smoothly behind the curtain starting with the AI Discovery workshop used to identify and select the Invoice Assistant scenario to an application demo which helps you determine whether scenarios are embedded AI features or GenAI Hub custom AI use cases on SAP BTP. You will also explore that Invoice Assistant architecture and resources for building your own Invoice Assistant.
Join us to step behind the curtain to see how AI transformed invoice management into a well-choreographed act.
 
Speakers
  • Sally Lawler Kennedy, SAP
  • Carlos Estala, SAP
  • Kay Schmitteckert, SAP

entry.title: Re: Error: Missing Authorization (S_ADMI_FCD, PADM) When...
entry.content:
Hello @Manasa131,

more details would help to find the solution easier.

1) What SAP GRC Foundation version & SP are you running in central system? And what GRCPINW version is installed in connected system/s SPM activated?

2) Is SPM newly implemented or it was already done in the and working till now?

3) Has this auth issue appeared in the past? Or is quite new?

4) Has happened any update/patch/upgrade or any change in GRC or target SAP system, including role change/s, and then this auth error started to appear? Or just appears with no clear relations?

5) Have you tried to trace and check it in detail? And have you extended the role for FFID by missing auth objects? If yes, any progress seen?

In general, this is obvious missing auth situation so standard procedure should be used to solve it.

I've seen similar missing authorization reported by FFID Users but everytime as impact of previous changes.

BR, Olga

entry.title: Blog 2: SAP EWM ‚Äì Smart Handling Multiple Equipment Types with intelligent WO Prioritization, LSD
entry.content:
Blog 2: SAP EWM ‚Äì Smart Handling Multiple Equipment Types with intelligent WO Prioritization, LSD Rounding, and Priority Updates via Resource Execution

Reference Blog 1: Handling Multiple Equipment Types through resource type for RF Processing.

In Blog 1, we explained how the multiple equipment types handled for distribution warehouse using EWM resource type solution. 

In this blog we will see how we can prioritize different Warehouse orders, based on business requirements.  There can be business requirement to reprioritize the WOs based on moves from Layer Drop area to Wrap area. Or different movements need to prioritize over other WOs. 

In this blog will see how we handled that for our big size distribution Center warehouses. 

this blog dives deeper into Work Order (WO) prioritization, Latest Starting Date (LSD) rounding, and how resource execution priorities influence WO assignment‚Äîespecially for high-reach equipment types.

There are 2 ways a WO can be assigned to a resource:

  1. Manually assigned WO : The warehouse manager assigns a WO to the resource via the Assign Rsrce warehouse management monitor method.
  2. The resource requests work by choosing a system-guided option from the RF menu. In such a case, the system assigns to the resource the most appropriate WO. 

How SAP EWM Determines the Most Suitable WO

When multiple WOs fall within the same queue classification, SAP EWM uses the following sorting logic:

  1. Ascending order by Latest Starting Date (LSD)
    ‚Üí Ensures tasks with earlier deadlines are prioritized.
  2. Descending order by Execution Priority
    ‚Üí Higher priority tasks are selected first if LSDs are equal.

    Below configs steps required to achieve

    • Time intervals and units of measure for rounding of LSD
    • Determination and use of execution priority.

     

    Configurations :-

    1. Define Mode

       

       

    2. Defined the modes determination based on various activities

       

    3. Define priority at process type level. (Not mandatory, this also can be managed through execution priority)

      Settings:-

      1. /SCWM/EXECPR - Master Data -> Resource Management -> Maintain Execution Priorities

      So we will make 2 settings here, we will assign the execution priority to the Bin Access Types against the resource type, this will make sure high-reach resources types / equipment types will receive high-reach-specific WOs first.

       

      SAP EWM uses a standard formula to calculate execution priority based on Bin Access Types (BAT):

      Execution Priority = (Source Bin BAT + Destination Bin BAT) / 2

      Customizing for High-Reach Tasks

      To ensure that high-reach tasks are prioritized for high-reach resource types, we apply the following configuration:

      • Assign Priority = 2 to the High Rack Bin Access Type (HR01).
      • All other BATs remain at Priority = 0.

      Thus, execution priority = (0+2)/2= 1 is automatically assigned to high-reach tasks, ensuring they are picked up first by high-reach equipment.

      Next mainatin execution priroty against the Specific Warehouse Process type. All the WOs against this WPT will get the default execution priroty as 01.

      Note:- Another important setting here, without this, system will not assign the priority to the WO :

      Maintain Mode Priority Weighting

       

      We have to assign the % of weightage against the each modes created in config step 1

      Final formula to calculate WO priority as below

      WO Priority = (BAT Weighting/100 x BAT Priority Value) + (HUTG Weighting/100 x HUTG Priority Value) + (WPC Weighting/100 x WPC Priority Value)

       

      Note : The total priority of the WO is set from the highest priority of its constituent WTs.

      Testing Scenario A: Prioritizing WO from specific WT as per setting and LSD Rounding:-

      Lets create so WO with WPT 3070

      Lets check the WO Priority

      Also the LSD is rounded to 1 Hr based on config step 1.

       

      Testing Scenario B: high-reach resources types / equipment types will receive high-reach-specific WOs first.

      Based on the settings of priority in Bin access type, High reach resource got priority 01. Now this WO will be auto prioritize in System guided menu.

      Next blog we will see how the WO gets selected in System Guided interleaving menu (Advanced Interleaving SAP S4HANA 2022)

Conclusion: - So, in this blog we explained how SAP standard prioritizes WO, also we explained through configuration how we prioritize WOs based on different process types and how we prioritize the WOs based on bin access types., also the required settings for rounding of the LSD.

entry.title: Re: PDF forms generated from a custom CDS view
entry.content:
Hi @Rawel 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Extensibility in S4 HANA Cloud &  Custom CDS Views.

To summarise, the reason your CDS view YY1_TEST_PO does not appear in custom field and logic is because not all CDS views are eligible. Custom views that you create for reporting are not automatically available as extension anchors.

I recommend you build your custom CDS on top of a released CDS view, if you need to add fields for reporting. If you need to expose the view an API, you should set the CDS category to external API.

If you need to extend your purchase orders with custom fields, it is best to do this directly in CFL and not by creating a new standalone CDS view.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Steps for Generating the SAML Assertion to read the data from the Successfactors using IAS
entry.content:
@babruvahana : Thanks for your queries ! As you have reached out here and LinkedIn , I tried the possible way to avoid using the username and password to generate the token from the IAS. I tried in postman but you can use in similar way in your application. 

First you go to applications & Resources and choose the OIDCTOKEN and change the Grant Types to Authorization code . Maintain also the Redirect URLs to https://oauth.pstmn.io/v1/callback , in your case it should be IAS application url/callback. 

If you put this url in your browser , you see the login screen of IAS , in my case it is id and password , no SSO so it will asked me and i can pass my email to login.https://XXXXXXaccounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/authorize?response_type=code&client_id=XXXc4626-d868-42f0-8f8d-8273aaXXXX&redirect_uri=https://oauth.pstmn.io/v1/callback&scope=openid&state=xyz123

After this call, you can see the authorization code in the call back URL which you need to keep in OIDCTOKEN like this in the browser https://oauth.pstmn.io/v1/callback?code=3e16afa987f65c18c56c1dXXXXXXX&iss=https%3A%2F%2FXXXXXXXaccounts.ondemand.com&state=xyz123

Use this code and go to postman and try to retrieve the authorization token. 

https://XXXXXX.accounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/token?grant_type=authorization_code&code=3e16afa987f65c18c56c1dXXXXXXX&redirect_uri=https://oauth.pstmn.io/v1/callback&client_id=XXXc4626-d868-42f0-8f8d-8273aaXXXX and you will be able to generate it.

Hope this will help you.

Thanks 

 

Best Regards,

Ajit Chirania.

entry.title: Re: How do I add international freight and insurance cost...
entry.content:
In Public Cloud, landed costs like freight and insurance cannot be managed via separate POs if you want them to roll into inventory. The recommended process is to create one PO for the material, then use the Manage Landed Costs app to capture freight and insurance charges and allocate them to the material. This way, you can still post separate invoices for each vendor, and the system will automatically update the material‚Äôs landed cost.

Freight and insurance costs should not be separate POs if the intent is to capitalize them into inventory. Instead record these costs as landed cost documents after goods receipt. Allocate them to the material based on quantity, weight, or value. Post supplier invoices separately for the freight forwarder and insurance company. The system will automatically adjust the inventory valuation (MAP or standard cost) so that the material reflects the full landed cost. This ensures:

  • Separate invoices can still be processed for each vendor.
  • Automatic landed cost capitalization into inventory.
  • Compliance with Public Cloud standard processes (no custom ABAP, no shipment cost documents).

entry.title: SAP KSA Localization: Cancelling Downpayment eDocuments Submitted to ZATCA
entry.content:
Under the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia‚Äôs eInvoicing mandate governed by ZATCA (Zakat, Tax and Customs Authority), taxpayers are required to submit structured eDocuments for various customer billing transactions. One commonly practiced scenario involves the reversal or cancellation of a downpayment invoice.

Key Considerations

ZATCA‚Äôs published Einvoicing implementation standards does not define a separate invoice type for reversing downpayment invoices. This can raise following queries when attempting to cancel such documents within SAP‚Äôs eDocument framework.

Will the amounts in the reversal edocument have negative signs?

If the invoice type code is 386 for the reversal document also, will it become a duplicate?

How will ZATCA know if the reversal document is a reversal or cancellation of the previously submitted downpayment edocument?

Required Process

To answer the above questions and remain compliant with ZATCA‚Äôs standards: the below process is to be followed.

  •  The cancellation accounting document should be a separate document type defined for downpayment cancellation and must be first mapped to invoice type code 381 in the value mapping (INVOICE_TYPE_CODE_FI), which represents a regular credit note.
  • The reference of the previously issued and submitted down payment document number will be automatically mentioned in the reversal document when the previously issued and submitted downpayment document number is canceled using FB08 transaction. this clarifies that the document is a reversal or cancellation of the original downpayment document.
  • This mapping applies even if the original document was a downpayment invoice (type 386).
  • No custom or alternative invoice type should be used for this reversal scenario.

This ensures that the cancellation is correctly interpreted by ZATCA‚Äôs platform and avoids submission errors or audit complications.

Other blogs on KSA eInvoicing

Solution onboarding guide

Master data mapping in KSA eInvoicing solution | SAP Blogs

One time Customer transactions in KSA eInvoicing | SAP Blogs

Handling Intercompany transactions in KSA eInvoicing | SAP Blogs

 
Some useful links

    • SAP Document Compliance topic page
    • Document Compliance Help Page
    • Announcement Legal Notification
    • KSA eInvoicing Webinar (Login required)
    • Saudi Arabia E-Invoice Webinar 28Sep2022.pdf (sapjam.com) (Login required)
    • [Release announcement] Phase 2 Solution for Saudi Arabia Electronic Invoicing

 Note: For accessing the last three links listed above you need to login to MENA Localization SIG ‚Äì Overview (sapjam.com)

#SAPCommunity#SAPS4HANA #SAPBlog #FinanceTransformation#TaxTechnology#ERPCompliance

entry.title: Re: Account Assignment Q (Project Stock) - possible for S...
entry.content:
Please note
P (Project) ‚Üí Used when you want to procure directly to a WBS element (consumption posting). Stock is not managed separately; costs are posted directly to the project.

Q (Project Stock) ‚Üí Used when you want to manage project stock separately in inventory (special stock Q). This requires a material number because the system needs to track stock quantities and values at WBS level.

Services do not create stock. They are always consumption‚Äëbased (posted to cost objects). Since Q means ‚Äúproject stock‚Äù (inventory managed at WBS level), it cannot be combined with services. Therefore, Account Assignment Q is not possible for services.

When you create a PR with only a material group and description (no material master), the system treats it as a consumption item. Again, no stock is updated, so project stock (Q) cannot be used. That‚Äôs why you get the error message related to BSX (inventory posting) ‚Äî the system expects a material master to determine valuation class and post to stock, but it cannot find one. Therefore, Account Assignment Q is not possible without a material number.

Now coming to your issue, ‚ÄúDocument cannot be posted: For KTOSL = BSX, KATYP cannot be 01‚Ä¶‚Äù. As you know, BSX = Inventory posting key and the system is trying to post to stock (because of Q), but since you used a service or a free‚Äëtext material, there is no stock account determination possible. This is not a missing customizing issue ‚Äî it‚Äôs a conceptual restriction.

In short,

  • Q requires a material master and stock management.
  • Services and free‚Äëtext items must use P.

entry.title: Plant abroad scenario of Inbound Message Handler for Poland solution
entry.content:
This blog post is intended to describe the enablement of plant abroad scenario of Inbound Message Handler on both SAP S/4HANA and SAP ERP releases for Poland.

PLEASE NOTE: the plant abroad scenario can only be executed when the company code belongs to a different country if compared to the country assigned to the message type.


Disclaimer: The plant abroad scenario only works if the new features of Inbound Message Handler are activated. Please check below:

In SAP S/4HANA and SAP ERP

SM30 ‚Üí EDOGENCUSTV

Country-specific steps to be executed

Steps to be executed by either country teams or customer inhouse developers *

In  SAP S/4HANA and SAP ERP

Create/edit an entry for the new/existing message type:

S4H OP 2023 and 2022

S4H 2021 and lower

EDOM

SM30 ‚Üí EDOMSGTYPEV

Assign it to the country, select the Message Group "Pulling" , Message Type "PL_KSEF_QRY_MSG_PULL" and "PL_KSEF_SESSION_PULL" and flag the ‚ÄúPlant abroad‚Äù checkbox:

EDOM:

 

SM30 ‚Üí EDOMSGTYPEV

 

Inbound Message Handler Report (TA EDOC_INBOUND_MSG)

The flag becomes available for use and the scenario can be executed.

This is how you enable the plants abroad scenario for Poland in the Inbound Message Handler.

entry.title: Customer Insights Dashboard Enhanced with Customer Overview Card
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce the availability of the new Customer Overview Card in the Customer Insights Dashboard. This feature provides a consolidated view of key customer and partner information at a glance.

Customer Insights Dashboard Enhanced with Customer Overview Card

We are pleased to announce the availability of the new Customer Overview Card in the Customer Insights Dashboard. This feature provides a consolidated view of key customer and partner information at a glance.

The Customer Overview Card is now available in the Summary tab and provides a snapshot of the customer data selected in the main navigation area at the top of the dashboard. Positioned at the top of the Summary section, it offers quick access to the most important account details‚Äîserving as a Customer Factsheet right at your fingertips.

Select a customer to get an overview of customer details

 

What You‚Äôll Find in the Customer Overview Card

The card combines both core customer data and information in relation to SAP.

Basic Customer Information

  • Number of customer accounts selected (from the main filter area)
  • Selected customer name(s)
  • ERP number
  • Account number
  • Corporate hierarchy details
  • Region
  • Country
  • Industry

Contractual Details

  • SAP customer since (start date)
  • Cloud customer since (start date)
  • Customer type 
  • Partner level

Why It Matters

With the Customer Overview Card, you no longer need to click through multiple sections to find basic account information. Everything is presented in one clear snapshot ‚Äî helping you:

  • Save time by quickly validating the customer accounts you‚Äôre working on.
  • Understand context at a glance, thanks to corporate hierarchy and industry details.
  • See relationships with partner status, customer type, and partner level in one place.

This new feature adds clarity and transparency to your dashboard experience and makes it easier to navigate complex customer structures.

Explore the new Customer Overview Card in the Customer Insights Dashboard today and experience how it simplifies your daily work.

Related Blog: 

  • SAP Adoption PDF Report generator in Customer Insights 
  • All related blogs for Customer Insights Dashboard

entry.title: Support Entitlement Made Clearer - New Enhancements in the Customer Insights Dashboard
entry.content:
Ever felt overwhelmed by SAP abbreviations, especially when trying to understand your support entitlements? We‚Äôve heard this feedback and introduced improvements in the Customer Insights Dashboard (CID) to make things more transparent.

Clearer View of Support Contracts and Premium Entitlements

We‚Äôve separated the main support contract types from the premium entitlements that can be added on top. This is now presented in a simple table with three columns:

  1. Support contract code (e.g., CES, CPS, MA, PSLE)
  2. Full contract title (so you don‚Äôt have to decode acronyms)
  3. Premium entitlement and attributes

 

With this view, it‚Äôs easy to see which contracts your company holds and which premium options are attached. The table is available in the Support Contract filter at the top of CID. You can, for example, focus on Cloud Enterprise Support (CES) to view only relevant details across the dashboard.

Support Entitlement Section: What‚Äôs New

The Support Entitlement section now provides a complete overview of:

  • Your valid main support contracts, such as SAP Enterprise Support, SAP Standard Support, SAP Preferred Success, or SAP PSLE.
  • Any additional premium engagements (e.g., Active Embedded, MaxAttention, Preferred Care).
  • Related Premium Engagement Attributes (PE Attributes) like SLA, Premium SLA, or Accelerated Case Management.

Entitlements and attributes are shown at both installation and system level, with two dedicated sub-areas:

  • By Installation
  • By System

Improved Graphs and Interactivity

  • In the By System graph, the Y-axis now shows support contracts, while the X-axis displays PE attributes‚Äîmaking their relationship much clearer.
  • All graphs and tables are interconnected: selecting a filter in one area instantly updates the others.
  • The Support Entitlement detail table at the bottom has also been updated to include full titles for contracts and premium entitlements, so you don‚Äôt have to cross-reference acronyms.

Why This Matters

These enhancements make it far easier to see your company‚Äôs contract landscape at a glance, understand premium attributes, and filter the dashboard according to what‚Äôs most relevant for you.

Related Blogs: 

  • All related blogs for Customer Insights Dashboard

entry.title: Check the Onboarding Status of Your Systems in Customer Insights Dashboard ‚Äì Part 2
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce that the Onboarding section of the Customer Insights Dashboard now includes SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition data in addition to the existing SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) information.

With this enhancement, customers can track their Customer Project Implementation by SAP software product. The Onboarding section visualizes progress across key milestones such as System Setup, Access Test System, Start Data Load, Access Prod System, Start Cut-Over, and System Go-Live, based on actual system usage.

How It Works

The onboarding process for both test and production systems follows several phases ("milestones or touchpoints‚Äù) that must be completed, especially when implementing the first system of a newly purchased product.

  • SAP EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) monitors these systems starting from the moment a test system is provisioned and provides onboarding status updates based on actual system usage.
  • Following the launch of SAP IBP onboarding in February 2025, the same functionality is now available for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with its own onboarding milestones.

Previously, this section was hidden by default and only visible through personalization settings in the dashboard. With the addition of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Onboarding tab is now displayed by default when users access the Customer Insights Dashboard.

What You Will See

The Onboarding section presents a status overview of milestones, categorized as Reached, Not Reached, or Overdue. This makes it easy to confirm progress and identify areas where support may be needed. If milestones are not reached or are overdue, recommendations are provided in the SAP EarlyWatch Alert apps to help resolve issues.

‚ÄÉ

Onboarding typically consists of a pair of systems (TEST and PROD). The dashboard graph shows their progress across milestones. If a system pair remains at one milestone for too long, its rating changes accordingly. Both the rating and onboarding data are collected from executed SAP EarlyWatch Alert reports.

By clicking on a milestone, users can access detailed information about the milestone, the relevant systems, and the reasons behind the current rating. A direct link to the associated SAP EarlyWatch Alert report provides further insights.

What‚Äôs Next

More products will be integrated into the Onboarding section soon ‚Äî stay tuned.

Related Blogs: 

  • Check the Onboarding Status of Your Systems in Customer Insights Reporting - Part 1
  • Track Your Cloud Journey: New Onboarding Milestones in SAP EarlyWatch Alert
  • All Related Blogs for Customer Insights Dashboard

entry.title: Event enabling SAP Data Replication Framework with Advanced Event Mesh & RAP Business Events
entry.content:
Introduction

With todays enterprise landscapes becoming more and more distributed data movement and distribution is getting more and more relevant. In this blog I will go through the steps necessary to connect the SAP Data Replication Framework (DRF) with the SAP Integration Suite - Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) using RAP Business Events.

 

Disclaimer

The clean core approach for a connection between DRF and AEM, and I would recommend to apply this pattern, would be the Usage of a Standard DRF Replications provided by SAP which target an Iflow on Integration Suite (SOAP, XI or IDoc Sender Adapter) and pass the Event to AEM using the AEM Adapter. This would be a configuration only scenario and also can be monitored with SAP Application Interface Framework. 

The pattern explained in this blog is bypassing the BTP Cloud Integration and connecting to AEM directly. In addition especially for complex data structures a lot of development effort is required which makes it impractical for many use cases.

Prerequisites

This blog assumes that an AEM instance has already been setup and is connected to your S/4HANA system. Check out this blog for a detailed setup guide.

 

Setup

The setup of this pattern consists of two parts. The first one is the modelling of the event itself and the second one the required setup to trigger the event from the DRF. We'll be creating the event and everything required for it, as well as creating a custom DRF outbound implementation.

Creating the Event

Before we can send data as events to the AEM we need to develop the event itself. You can checkout this link for a details blog on how to create such events. To start lets create our BO to hold the event, starting with the initial data definition. For this blog I'll be replicating business partner data as such I'll be using the I_BusinessPartner view as root for my BO.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Business Partner BO for DRF 2 RAP Events'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP as select from I_BusinessPartner
{
    
    key BusinessPartner
}

 Next lets build the behaviour definition on top of it:

managed with unmanaged save implementation in class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;
}

Next we need to define the event payload itself. According to the exact requirements the payload needs to be modeled accordingly in the abstract entity. Check out this blog to see how to create more complex payloads with deep structures. In this example I'll be creating just a very simple payload with the first and last name. The business partner number will automatically be included in the event as the key field of the BO.

@EndUserText.label: 'Payload for BP DRF'
define abstract entity Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP_PAYLOAD
{
    FirstName : abap.char(40);
    LastName : abap.char(40);
    
}

Next lets define the event itself on the behaviour definition. Reference the abstract entity and don't forget the deep keyword if you are using a nested payload structure.

managed with unmanaged save implementation in class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;

  event DRF_REPLICATION parameter Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP_PAYLOAD;
}

 Next we can define the implementation class for our BO. As events can only be triggered within the implementation class of a BO we need to create and expose a wrapper method that we later can call from the DRF. For this lets define a class-method within our global class. This method should import the business partner number so that we can raise the specific event.

CLASS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp DEFINITION PUBLIC ABSTRACT FINAL FOR BEHAVIOR OF z_drf_2_rap_bp.

    PUBLIC SECTION.
        CLASS-METHODS raise_drf_event
            IMPORTING iv_bp TYPE BU_PARTNER.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp IMPLEMENTATION.

    METHOD raise_drf_event.
        lcl_event_handler=>on_Raise_DRF_Event( iv_bp ).
    ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

We can then raise the event within the local types. I've added a select to collect all of the required data for the business partner and pass it to the event.

CLASS lcl_event_handler DEFINITION FRIENDS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS on_Raise_DRF_Event IMPORTING iv_bp TYPE BU_PARTNER.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_handler IMPLEMENTATION.
   METHOD on_Raise_DRF_Event.

    DATA: tt_events TYPE TABLE FOR EVENT z_drf_2_rap_bp~drf_replication.

    SELECT SINGLE
        BusinessPartner, FirstName, LastName
        FROM I_BusinessPartner
        WHERE BusinessPartner = @( |{ iv_bp ALPHA = IN }| )
        INTO (s_bupa).

    tt_events = VALUE #(
        (
            businesspartner = s_bupa-BusinessPartner
            firstName = s_bupa-FirstName
            lastName = s_bupa-LastName
        )
    ).

    RAISE ENTITY EVENT z_drf_2_rap_bp~drf_replication FROM tt_events.

   ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

Next lets create the event binding to assign the event a topic:

 

After everything is activated you can call this method from any context to trigger the event.

 

DRF Customising

The customising of the DRF is nearly identical to the one described in Alex blog about connecting DRF with AIFAEM.

The standard object we are trying to use is 986 - Business Partner. You'll find it in DRFIMG -> Enhance Default Settings for Outbound Implementations -> Define Business Objects. The corresponding Outbound Implementation (using the standard SOAP Proxy) is 986_3. For our use case we need a custom Outbound Implementation based on this object. As such we need to copy the object to a new custom one. I named mine Z_986_3_RP

To be able to connect our RAP business event with DRF we need to adjust the outbound implementation class. Therefore we need to copy the standard implementation class of 986_3 (CL_MDG_BS_BP_REL_SERVICE_DRF) to a new custom class and reference it in our Outbound Implementation class Z_986_3_RP. I named mine Z_CL_DRF_2_RAP_BP_REPL

The class is referencing itself at multiple points. This needs to be adjusted to the new Z-Class. In addition some further mappings have to be performed which Alex described in his blog. The complete coding for the implementation of this blog can be found in the attached txt file.

The most important adjustment is however the call to our previously defined wrapper method raise_drf_event in our implementation class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp. For this I added a loop over the different entries which calls this method and passes the business partner number.

LOOP AT ls_rap_raw-business_partner_suitereplicat INTO DATA(ls_entry).

                DATA(ev_bp) = ls_entry-business_partner-internal_id.

                TRY.
                    CALL METHOD zbp_drf_2_rap_bp=>raise_drf_event
                     EXPORTING
                      iv_bp = ev_bp.

                CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_root).
                 MESSAGE lx_root->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
                ENDTRY.
            ENDLOOP.

Depending on the required payload of the event this can be further improved by removing the select from the method implementation and passing the data directly from the original structure.

This new Outbound Implementation needs to be assigned to a replication model.

 

This also needs to be activated within "Define Replication Model" level.

 

Test

To test this setup lets replicate the following business partner:

Create the event binding by opening transaction /IWXBE/OUTBOUND_CFG, selecting your broker and creating a new topic binding for your respective topic

 

Open transaction DRFOUT and select your replication model

Also set the manual filter criteria:

 

Press execute. The logs should then display a success.

The event itself can then be viewed in the Event Monitor (transaction /IWXBE/EVENT_MONITOR)

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics 2509 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New?
entry.content:
The latest changes in SAP Business Network for Logistics bring tighter integration, richer data, and more guidance at your fingertips. The updates across Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace introduce new code-list values, enhanced APIs, improved in-app help, stronger connection controls, and expanded tracking capabilities. Here‚Äôs a concise look at what‚Äôs new and what it means for carriers, shippers, data contributors, and solution owners.

 

Cross SAP Business Network for Logistics

‚ÄòSystem Connection‚Äô app: Maintain logical system IDs

You can now maintain the Logical system ID when creating a connection in the ‚ÄòSystem Connection‚Äô app. This setting helps users avoiding duplicated tracking records and reduces the effort needed for configuring document links across Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace.

Enhancement to OAuth2.0 authentication

Beyond client credentials, carriers and data providers can now also use a client certificate (key pair) for OAuth 2.0 authentication of outbound connections. This strengthens security and adherence to your organization‚Äôs authentication requirements.

New parameter in Consumer API for Order Tracking (FC and GTT)

SAP Business Accelerator Hub: Consumer API for Order Tracking ‚Äî In the Consumer API for Order Tracking (GTT) and Consumer API for Order Tracking (FC), a new parameter, serviceLevel, is added to the shipment object. It denotes the scope of agreed service provided by carriers or data contributors (e.g., milestone tracking, real-time tracking, ETA updates).

 

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration

Code lists: New value in Document Reference Type Codes

The Document Reference Type Codes code list now includes ‚ÄòReturn Sales Order (32)‚Äô. This enhancement expands reference types in documentation workflows, benefiting carriers and shippers.

New field in ‚ÄòConsumer API for Freight Booking‚Äô

A new field was added in the carrier‚Äôs ‚ÄòConsumer API for Freight Booking‚Äô. The ‚ÄòCustoms Commodity Classification Code‚Äô has been added at the item level to improve classification accuracy.

Dock Appointment Scheduling: In-app help for gate and yard

The ‚ÄòManage Entities‚Äô app now includes in-app help for selected fields on the gate and yard sections, such as 'Arrival Lead Time' and 'Assignment with Yards'. You can access the help by selecting the help icon in the top-right corner.

Dock Appointment Scheduling: Enhanced stop information

Stop information in the ‚ÄòManage Dock Appointments‚Äô and ‚ÄòSelf-Book Dock Appointments‚Äô apps now display arrival and departure timestamps, resolving discrepancies where loading and departure dates differed. The stops section supports appointments based on freight orders. If the ‚ÄòUse Derived Appointment Duration‚Äô toggle is enabled for a loading point, the derived duration is calculated from the requested start and end dates for loading/unloading.

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: sunset functionality to manually update external appointments

Manual updates to external appointment dates/times are no longer supported in the ‚ÄòManage Dock Appointments‚Äô and ‚ÄòSelf-Book Dock Appointments‚Äô apps.

 

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace

API documentation now available in HTML version

The new API Documentation is now available in the HTML version on the product page. It consolidates content on public APIs and GTT backend service interfaces that were previously scattered across two guides.

‚ÄòManage Models‚Äô app: new field ‚ÄòIsFinal‚Äô added

New completion-logic fields improve tracking fidelity, status calculations, and visibility across shipments, freight units, and related processes. In the standard model "gttft1," a new field ‚ÄòIs Final‚Äô is added as a standard model field to all event types. It indicates whether an actual event is the last milestone event.

All fulfillment tracking apps: completion logic enhanced

Upon customer request, processes can be set to complete when the visibility provider flags and event ‚ÄòisFinal = true‚Äô. For example, an unloading event might set the status of the business document (shipment, freight unit, tracking unit or outbound delivery) to ‚ÄòCompleted‚Äô.

 ---------------------

The above summarizes the key innovations for 2509. We hope you enjoy the new capabilities. Thanks for reading the blog post and stay tuned! 

A full overview of the 2509 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

entry.title: Re: How to activate the feature SD_SLS_PRNT_ALL_TXT_LANG
entry.content:
Hello!

Since the release 2508, this feature has been enabled by default on the system, which means the activation is not necessary anymore.

To ensure the behavior is the desired, make sure the following configuration activities are setup:

  • Define Text Types for SD Document Header (ID: 105684)
  • Define Text Types for SD Document Item (ID: 105685)

For maintaining the texts, follow the steps bellow:

  1. Change the system language for the same language as the needed for the text to appear, e.g.: Portuguese (PT).
  2. Go to the configuration activity where this text type was created (header or item)
  3. Maintain the description for the text on this language.
  4. Repeat those steps for each language the text should exist.

entry.title: Re: When will Crystal Reports implement SVG?
entry.content:
To let people know what SVG graphics are here's a description:

SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics, an XML-based vector image format for creating 2D graphics, charts, and illustrations on the web. Unlike pixel-based formats (like JPEG or PNG), SVG images are defined by mathematical formulas, allowing them to be scaled to any size without losing quality. They are text-based, making them searchable, indexable, and scriptable, and they support animation, interactivity, and styling with CSS. 

It's complicated.... CRD was created in the mid 90's, well before SVG was around, it was all based on C++ runtime and uses Microsoft's MEMSize for internal memory handling. According to wikipedia SVG was created in 1999.

To speed report creations, Viewing etc. CR converts all images into BMP format to reduce the file size when using Saved Data etc.

Since this image type is interactive the reports, for example a warehouse inventory report, would likely cause the report to be in giga-bytes, thus causing memory issues when viewing in WEB based app's and Desktop app's.

So it would be nice to use this feature but CR would have issues using it.

Possibly @IDO has a UFL that could use it.

 There is a site to request Enhancements but it requires a Support Contract to access....

So likely there never will be this feature added...

entry.title: Re: List of SAP Power Designer all versions links (url) f...
entry.content:
I'll begin by providing detailed information regarding the versions. This will help ensure we are aligned and can proceed with troubleshooting.

Product version look like this:
E.g: Latest version : PowerDesigner 16.7 SP09 PL01

- Release Software level version is : 16.7 ( Family number)

- SP (Software Package) Level version is : SP09 (Latest Package)

- PL (Patch Level) is : 01
A patch level is a collection of fixes that are added to an SP. A PL contains only bug fixes, not new features.


1*** PowerDesigner 16.7  with Windows 2016 operating system 
KBA##2347515 - What is the list of supported Windows operating systems? - SAP PD 

2*** PowerDesigner 16.7 with Windows 2022 operating system
KBA##3202469 - Can PowerDesigner be installed on Windows Server 2022 - SAP PD 

If you have successfully installed SAP PowerDesigner version 16.7.8.3 on Windows 2016, please note that all other versions within the 16.7 package family are also compatible with the Windows 2016 operating system.

I‚Äôd like to confirm that you can install PowerDesigner starting from version 16.7 SP00 on both Windows Server 2016 and Windows Server 2022 operating system versions. This compatibility ensures that all versions of PowerDesigner, beginning with version 16.7  (SP00 / SP01/SP02 /SP03/ SP04/ SP05/ SP06/ SP07/ SP08/ SP09) , are supported on these platforms.

entry.title: Migrating from SAP Solution Manager ChaRM To SAP Cloud ALM, how to map Types of Changes
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are currently using SAP Solution Manager ChaRM with change document type:

  • Normal
  • Urgent
  • Standard

We don't use approval for Standard Changes.

How do we implement the same process in SAP Cloud ALM? Can we differentiate the Features in a way that we can know which are Urgent, Standard, and Normal? From the documentation we only see Requirements and Features. But if i have an Urgent Change in SAP Solution Manager ChaRM want to replicate the same in SAP Cloud ALM, how do i differentiate the Features which are Urgent ,Normal and Standard?

Kind Regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Migrating from SAP Solution Manager ChaRM To SAP Clou...
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ALM offers only 1 flavour of Change Document: Features.

There are (conceptually) no Urgent, Normal, or Standard Changes in SAP Cloud ALM. However it is possible to achieve a similar workflow. 

When you create a Feature in SAP Cloud ALM, there are optional fields in the "Additional Information" section. These include:

  • Workstream
  • Tags
  • Priority
  • Release

Any one (or a combination of several) of these fields can be used to classify your Features like Solution Manager ChaRM Change Documents. These fields are also filter options in the SAP Cloud ALM Features app, so you can use them to display lists of Features that meet the conditions you establish for each type of conceptual Change Document.

For example, the "priority" field can be used to establish an internal process where: 

  • All "High" and "Very High" priority Features are treated as an "Urgent Change".
  • All "Medium" priority Features are treated as a "Normal Change".
  • All "low" priority Features can be considered as a "Standard Change". 

You could establish a work process where Developers check for all priority "High" and "Very High" Features, and work on them as Urgent Changes, etc.

Alternatively, you could create workstreams that must be assigned to Features if they are "Urgent", "Normal", or "Standard". Or you could use Releases in your projects for each type of change. Features can also be "tagged" with keywords for their type (Urgent, Normal, etc.).

In summary, because SAP Cloud ALM doesn't provide different Feature sub-types, we don't have have a prescriptive way of classifying them as per the SAP Solution Manager ChaRM concepts. Our additional fields and filtering options give flexibility to choose a way of working that matches your desired workflow. But these must be established as internal processes, and are not enforced by the Features app.
